title: Nicer-looking histogram — Hist
code: Hist(   x,   ...,   col = "gray",   border = "white",   n = 10,   breaks = seq(min(x, na.rm = TRUE), max(x, na.rm = TRUE), len = n),   main = "",   las = 1,   xlab = deparse(substitute(x)) )

title: Nicer-looking histogram — Hist
text: x vector values make histogram ... arguments hist() col Fill color histogram bars; default: gray border Border (outline) histogram bars; default: white n Number bins breaks Specific locations bins constructed; overrides n main Main title; default: none las See par() xlab Just like every plot

title: Nicer-looking histogram — Hist
Customized plotting functions — Plot
text: Customized plotting functions

title: Customized plotting functions — Plot
code: Plot(obj, ...)  # S3 method for BinaryTree Plot(obj, pval = FALSE, summary = FALSE, digits = 1, ...)  # S3 method for rpart Plot(obj, summary = FALSE, digits = 1, ...)  # S3 method for survfit Plot(   obj,   legend = c("top", "right", "none"),   xlab = "Time",   ylab = "Survival",   col,   ... )

title: Customized plotting functions — Plot
text: obj Object plotted ... Additional arguments underlying plot function pval Show p-values branching nodes?  Default=FALSE summary Show summary statistics terminal nodes?  Default FALSE; plots drawn instead. digits Number digits show edges.  Default: 1. legend put legend. Either 'top', 'right', 'none'; default: 'top' xlab, ylab Axis labels. col Vector colors corresponding groups.

title: Customized plotting functions — Plot
code: # KM curves veteran <- survival::veteran fit <- survival::survfit(survival::Surv(time, status) ~ celltype, veteran) Plot(fit)   # Trees data(kyphosis, package='rpart') fit <- rpart::rpart(Kyphosis ~ Age + Number + Start, data = kyphosis) Plot(fit)  fit <- party::ctree(Kyphosis ~ Age + Number + Start, data = kyphosis) Plot(fit)  Plot(fit, summary=TRUE)  Plot(fit, summary=TRUE, pval=TRUE)  Plot(fit, pval=TRUE, digits=2)  Data <- kyphosis Data$Start <- Data$Start + runif(nrow(Data)) fit <- rpart::rpart(Kyphosis ~ Age + Number + Start, data = Data) Plot(fit)  Plot(fit, digits=10)

title: Show all duplicate entries in a data frame/table/vector — alldup
code: DF <- data.frame(x = 1:3, y = c(1, 1, 2)) alldup(DF, "x") #> [1] x y #> <0 rows> (or 0-length row.names) alldup(DF, "y") #>   x y #> 1 1 1 #> 2 2 1 alldup(DF$y) #> [1] 1 1

title: Bayesian analysis of one-sample binomial data using conjugate beta priors — binom_bayes
code: binom_bayes(   x,   n,   a = 1,   b = 1,   level = 0.95,   null,   plot = FALSE,   add = FALSE,   xlab = "p",   ylab = "Posterior density",   col = "blue",   ... )

title: Bayesian analysis of one-sample binomial data using conjugate beta priors — binom_bayes
text: x Number "successes" n Number trials 'alpha' parameter beta prior. Default: uniform prior b 'beta' parameter beta prior. Default: uniform prior level posterior interval; .95 95% credible interval null Point null evaluate kind hypothesis test plot Draw plot?  Default: false add Add existing plot?  Default: false xlab xlab plot ylab ylab plot col color density line plot ... Additional arguments plot()

title: Bayesian analysis of one-sample binomial data using conjugate beta priors — binom_bayes
code: binom_bayes(10, 16) #> Sample proportion: 0.625  #> Posterior mean: 0.611  #> Posterior mode: 0.625  #> Posterior SD: 0.112  #> 95% central interval: (0.383, 0.816) #> 95% HPD interval: (0.392, 0.823) binom_bayes(0, 21, plot=TRUE)  #> Sample proportion: 0.000  #> Posterior mean: 0.043  #> Posterior mode: 0.000  #> Posterior SD: 0.042  #> 95% central interval: (0.001, 0.154) #> 95% HPD interval: (0.000, 0.127)

what: Save and combine (gather) results from batched R sessions — bsave
title: Save and combine (gather) results from batched R sessions — bsave
text: bsave() run R; companion function run command line via gather, located Dropbox/bin.

title: Save and combine (gather) results from batched R sessions — bsave
Save and combine (gather) results from batched R sessions — bsave
text: res Results save suffix default, files named 'tmp1.rds', 'tmp2.rds', .  suffix='', files named 'tmp1-.rds', 'tmp2-.rds', etc.  gather save results '2018-11-07-.rds'.

title: Save and combine (gather) results from batched R sessions — bsave
code: # These examples are illustrative; for working examples, see Dropbox/bin/test  A <- rnorm(100)  # If run interactively # bsave(A)        # Saves to 2019-06-14.rds # bsave(A, "A")   # Saves to 2019-06-14-A.rds  # If run in batch (with a number as first command line argument) # bsave(A)        # Saves to tmp1.rds; gathered to 2019-06-14.rds # bsave(A, "A")   # Saves to tmp1-A.rds; gathered to 2019-06-14-A.rds

title: Catch warnings — catchWarning
text: mainly used code either () generates bunch warnings, makes hard find warning may happened 78 warnings ago, (b) generates warning error, hard get warning error causes code crash warning signalled.

title: Catch warnings — catchWarning
Catch warnings — catchWarning
text: expr R expression

title: Catch warnings — catchWarning
code: out <- catchWarning(log('a')) out$value #> <simpleError in log("a"): non-numeric argument to mathematical function> out <- catchWarning(as.numeric(c('1', 'a'))) out #> $value #> [1]  1 NA #>  #> $warning #> <simpleWarning in doTryCatch(return(expr), name, parentenv, handler): NAs introduced by coercion> #>  out <- catchWarning(1+1) out #> $value #> [1] 2 #>  #> $warning #> NULL #>

what: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
title: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
text: "Forest plot"-style plotting confidence intervals regression model. Basic input matrix columns estimate/lower/upper, along optional 4th column p-value. Also works variety models (lm/glm/coxph/etc).

title: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
code: ci_plot(obj, ...)  # S3 method for matrix ci_plot(   obj,   sort = TRUE,   diff = (ncol(obj) == 4),   null = 0,   trans,   p_label = FALSE,   ... )  # S3 method for lm ci_plot(obj, intercept = FALSE, exclude = NULL, plot = TRUE, tau, ...)  # S3 method for glm ci_plot(obj, ...)  # S3 method for mer ci_plot(   obj,   intercept = FALSE,   exclude = NULL,   plot = TRUE,   tau,   nsim = 500,   ... )  # S3 method for coxph ci_plot(obj, exclude = NULL, plot = TRUE, tau, ...)  # S3 method for data.frame ci_plot(obj, ...)

title: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
text: obj object plotted; can matrix raw values model object ... used sort Sort parameters estimate? (default: true) diff Include tests difference / p-values? null Draw line representing effect value (default: 0) trans Transformation applied (e.g., trans=exp log link) p_label Label p-values (p=0.02 instead just 0.02)? (default: FALSE) intercept Include CI intercept? (default: FALSE) exclude Variables exclude (character vector) plot FALSE, just returns matrix estimates/CIs/p-values plotted plot anything tau named vector effect sizes; CIs shown tau*beta. coefficients included given tau = 1. nsim Number simulations; see confint.merMod

title: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
text: -: stripes (https://ggplot2-book.org/annotations#sec-custom-annotations) auto sd interactions

title: Create forest plot of confidence intervals — ci_plot
code: # Supplying a matrix B <- cbind(1:3, 0:2, 2:4) rownames(B) <- LETTERS[1:3] ci_plot(B)   # Supplying a fitted model object fit <- lm(Ozone ~ Solar.R + Wind + Temp, airquality) ci_plot(fit)  ci_plot(fit, tau=c(Solar.R = 100, Temp = 10, Wind = 3))  ci_plot(fit, tau=c(Solar.R = 100))

Tab <- table(A=rnorm(100)>0, B=rnorm(100)>0) contingency_table(Tab) #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #> #>
B: No B: Yes
A: No 28 28
A: Yes 22 22

what: Power and sample size for time-to-event data based on exponential closed form solution — epower
title: Power and sample size for time-to-event data based on exponential closed form solution — epower
text: Power calculated two-sample studies.  Can vectorized, w, lam, cens, must always length 2.

title: Power and sample size for time-to-event data based on exponential closed form solution — epower
code: epower(n, r, alpha = 0.05, w = c(1, 1), n1, n2, lam, cens)  esamsize(r, w = c(1, 1), alpha = 0.05, power = 0.8, lam, cens)

title: Power and sample size for time-to-event data based on exponential closed form solution — epower
text: n Total sample size. r Effect size (ratio hazards/medians). alpha Type error rate. w Controls sample size balance two groups.  Default: Equal size groups. n1, n2 Sample size group. lam Hazard rate group (specified, overrides r). cens Censoring rate. power Desired power.  Default: 0.8.

title: Power and sample size for time-to-event data based on exponential closed form solution — epower

title: Estimate linear combinations from a regression model — estimate

code: estimate(fit, lambda, alpha = 0.05, t.test = inherits(fit, "lm"), trans)

title: Estimate linear combinations from a regression model — estimate
text: fit model coef() vcov() methods lambda Linear combination weights (numeric vector length equal number coefficients fit) alpha Error rate confidence interval (default: 0.05) t.test Use t distribution inference? (default: TRUE model linear) trans Apply transformation function results? (function)

title: Estimate linear combinations from a regression model — estimate
code: # Linear regression fit <- lm(Ozone ~ Wind + Temp + Solar.R, airquality) estimate(fit, c(0, 1, -1, 5)) #>      Estimate         Lower         Upper            SE             t  #> -4.686581e+00 -5.871574e+00 -3.501589e+00  5.977614e-01 -7.840221e+00  #>             p  #>  3.561935e-12   # Logistic regression DF <- as.data.frame(Titanic) DF <- DF[rep(1:nrow(DF), DF$Freq),] fit <- glm(Survived ~ Class + Sex + Age, DF, family=binomial) estimate(fit, c(0, 1, -1, 0, 0, 0), trans=exp) #>     Estimate        Lower        Upper           SE            t            p  #> 2.137565e+00 1.512603e+00 3.020742e+00           NA 4.307663e+00 1.722593e-05

title: Create a time-to-event chart using ggplot — event_chart
Create a time-to-event chart using ggplot — event_chart
text: Data data frame data.table dates, organized following way (first two columns plotted line segment, remaining columns plotted symbol): Column 1: Follow-start date Column 2: Follow-end date Additional columns: Additional events may occur follow-period shift Shift time 0 represents start follow-everyone? (default: FALSE) scale shifted, units? (default: scale=1, meaning days)

title: Create a time-to-event chart using ggplot — event_chart
code: df <- read.csv(system.file("extdata/cdcaids.txt", package="breheny")) event_chart(df, FALSE)  event_chart(df, TRUE)  event_chart(df, TRUE, 365.25)

Create a flowchart — flowchart
text: deep Whether make deep clone.

title: Create a flowchart — flowchart
code:
fl <- Flow$new("All children
(n=935)") fl$add("Returned form
(n=511)", parent=1) fl$add("Baseline: 0
(n=447)", parent=2, x=-1) fl$add("Baseline: 1 or 2
(n=14)", parent=2) fl$add("Baseline: 3
(n=50)", parent=2, x=1) fl$add("Initiation
(n=315)", parent=3, x=-1) fl$add("Completion
(n=276)", parent=6, x=-1) fl$add("Completion
(n=12)", parent=4) fl #>                      Label Parent  x #> 1    All children
(n=935)      0  0 #> 2   Returned form
(n=511)      1  0 #> 3     Baseline: 0
(n=447)      2 -1 #> 4 Baseline: 1 or 2
(n=14)      2  0 #> 5      Baseline: 3
(n=50)      2  1 #> 6      Initiation
(n=315)      3 -1 #> 7      Completion
(n=276)      6 -1 #> 8       Completion
(n=12)      4  0 #> Class: Flow plot(fl)  plot(fl, hpad=20, vpad=20)  plot(fl, xm=0.25)

code: grayCol('red', 0.5) #> [1] "#DF5F5F" plot(1:10, pch=19, col='red') points(2:10, pch=19, col=grayCol('red', 0.5)) points(3:10, pch=19, col=grayCol('red', 0.75)) points(4:10, pch=19, col=grayCol('red', 0.75, 0.1)) points(5:10, pch=19, col=grayCol('red', 0.75, 0.5))   grayCol(c('blue', 'red', 'green'), c(0.75, 0, 0.75), darkness=0.1) #> [1] "#ACACEC" "#FF0000" "#ACECAC" plot(1:3, pch=19, col=.Last.value) #> Warning: supplied color is neither numeric nor character

title: Plot likelihood function — likelihood_plot
text: plotL() plots likelihood, plotl() plots log-likelihood

title: Plot likelihood function — likelihood_plot
code: plotL(   x,   l,   xlab = expression(theta),   ylab = expression(L(theta)),   bty = "n",   col,   add = FALSE,   ... )  plotl(   x,   l,   xlab = expression(theta),   ylab = expression("\u2113" * (theta)),   bty = "n",   col,   add = FALSE,   ... )

title: Plot likelihood function — likelihood_plot
text: x Parameter values (x axis) l Likelihood / log-likelihood (y axis) xlab Default: theta ylab Default: L(theta) bty Default: boundary box col Color (vector colors, l matrix) add Add existing plot?  Default: FALSE ... arguments plot()

title: Plot likelihood function — likelihood_plot
code: x <- seq(-3, 4, length=99) L <- dnorm(1, x) l <- dnorm(1, x, log=TRUE) plotL(x, L)  plotl(x, l)  L <- cbind(dnorm(1, x), dnorm(2, x)) l <- cbind(dnorm(1, x, log=TRUE), dnorm(2, x, log=TRUE)) plotL(x, L)  plotl(x, l)

title: Make a log-scale axis — logAxis
code: x <- rexp(100) y <- runif(100) plot(log(x), y)  plot(log(x), y, xaxt='n', xlab='x') logAxis()  plot(log(x), y, xaxt='n', xlab='x') logAxis(style='pow', disp=2)

title: Make a PCA/tSNE/UMAP plot — pca_plot
text: X numeric matrix grp Optional grouping factor color instances txt Use rownames labels instead dots (default: false) method carry dimension reduction (pca/tsne/umap) dims Dimensions return (tsne) gg Use ggplot2? (default: true) ellipse Draw mvn-ellipses around groups? (default: false, available ggplot) legend Include legend (default: true) repel gg=TRUE txt=TRUE, use ggrepel::geom_text_repel()? (default: false) plot Create plot? (default: true) ... arguments plot()

what: Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd
title: Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd
text: function sets root-finding problem appropriate per-test cutoff alpha found satisfies supplied FDR (expectation), reports overall power tests carried alpha level.  Vectorized n, nothing else.

title: Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd
Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd
text: n Sample size (per group) p Number features (genes) d Number differential features (differentially expressed genes) m Minimum difference among differential features, terms mean difference divided SD (effect size) FDR Target FDR

title: Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd
text: list containing three items: expected_hits: Expected number discoveries (marginal power multiplied number differential features) marginal_power: Power detect given feature (function assumes features) disjunctive_power: Power detect least one feature

title: Power calculator for high-dimensional testing — power_hd

Numeric.  Default: 168 (1 week). r Output R code (opposed link)? default, function return links =stdout() R code otherwise. However, can overridden explicitly setting r TRUE FALSE.

what: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
title: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
text: Determine sample size necessary estimate probability correct classification (PCC) within certain tolerance optimal (Bayes) PCC.

title: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
text: effect Effect size (difference means divided SD) tolerance Sample size found \(PCC(\infty) - PCC(n)\) less tolerance. p Proportion less common class (default 0.5) nfeat Number features dfeat Number differential features. Note Dobbin & Simon recommend using dfeat=1.

title: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
text: Object class `power.htest``, list arguments augmented method note elements.

title: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
text: Assumes multivariate normal distribution spherical variance. Loosely based function MKmisc::ssize.pcc(), two primary differences: solve worst case scenario 1:dfeat, just uses dfeat. Uses tpower() rather approximating power t-test.

title: Sample size for classifier development — samsize_pcc
code: samsize_pcc(0.5, 0.001) #>  #>      Sample Size Planning for Developing Classifiers Using High Dimensional Data  #>  #>       tolerance = 0.001 #>               p = 0.5 #>          effect = 0.5 #>           nfeat = 1 #>           dfeat = 1 #>         pcc_inf = 0.5987063 #>           pcc_n = 0.5977528 #>              n1 = 34 #>              n2 = 34 #>  samsize_pcc(1, 0.1, nfeat=22000) #>  #>      Sample Size Planning for Developing Classifiers Using High Dimensional Data  #>  #>       tolerance = 0.1 #>               p = 0.5 #>          effect = 1 #>           nfeat = 22000 #>           dfeat = 1 #>         pcc_inf = 0.6914625 #>           pcc_n = 0.5946208 #>              n1 = 38 #>              n2 = 38 #>  samsize_pcc(0.8, 0.1, p=1/3, nfeat=22000, dfeat=20) #>  #>      Sample Size Planning for Developing Classifiers Using High Dimensional Data  #>  #>       tolerance = 0.1 #>               p = 0.3333333 #>          effect = 0.8 #>           nfeat = 22000 #>           dfeat = 20 #>         pcc_inf = 0.965748 #>           pcc_n = 0.86905 #>              n1 = 36 #>              n2 = 72 #>

text: x x positions (named); alternatively, 2-column matrix column row names y y positions, x matrix xlab x axis label ylab y axis label ... Additional arguments plot()

title: Scatter plot, but with text labels — textPlot
code: a <- runif(10) b <- runif(10) names(a) <- names(b) <- LETTERS[1:10] textPlot(a, b)   X <- cbind(a=a, b=b) textPlot(X)

what: Make a legend on top or right side of plot — toplegend

text: Make legend top right side plot

title: Make a legend on top or right side of plot — toplegend
Make a legend on top or right side of plot — toplegend
text: horiz Horizontal layout? ... arguments legend()

title: Make a legend on top or right side of plot — toplegend
code: g <- rbinom(20, 1, 0.5) x <- rnorm(20) y <- rnorm(20) plot(x, y, col=pal(2)[g+1], pch=19) toplegend(legend=c('Group 1', 'Group 2'), col=pal(2), pch=19)

what: Power for t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses — tpower
title: Power for t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses — tpower
text: Power t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses

title: Power for t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses — tpower
code: tpower(   n,   delta,   lam = c(1, -1),   b,   sd = 1,   alpha = 0.05,   w = rep(1, g),   n1,   n2,   verbose = (N == 1) )  tsamsize(delta, b = c(delta, 0), w = rep(1, g), power = 0.8, upper = 5000, ...)

title: Power for t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses — tpower
text: n Sample size (total). delta Effect size; specified, two-group design assumed.  two groups, use b instead. lam Contrast. b vector, coefficient group.  matrix, must length(n) rows. sd Standard deviation outcome. alpha Type error rate. w Weights unequal allocation (normalized 1). n1, n2 Sample size group 1, 2. verbose Print details power calculations.  Default: TRUE unless vectorized. power Desired power. upper Upper bound tsamsize(); increase tsamsize hits bound.  Default: 5000. ... tsamsize(), additional arguments passed tpower().

title: Power for t tests, including arbitrary linear hypotheses — tpower

what: Generate fixed width file in R — write_fwf
title: Generate fixed width file in R — write_fwf
text: https://gist.github.com/haozhu233/28d1309b58431f4929f78243054f1f58

title: Generate fixed width file in R — write_fwf
code: write_fwf(dt, width, con = stdout(), align = "l", na = "NA", col.names = TRUE)

title: Generate fixed width file in R — write_fwf
text: dt data printed width Either single number vector widths con Connection, writeLines(); default stdout(). align "l", "r" something like "lrl" left, right, left. na print places missing values; default: "NA" col.names Print column names?  Default: TRUE

title: Generate fixed width file in R — write_fwf
code: dt <- data.frame(a = 1:3, b = NA, c = c('a', 'b', 'c')) write_fwf(dt, width = c(4, 4, 3)) #> a   b   c   #> 1   NA  a   #> 2   NA  b   #> 3   NA  c   write_fwf(dt, 5) #> a    b    c     #> 1    NA   a     #> 2    NA   b     #> 3    NA   c      X <- matrix(LETTERS[1:9], 3, 3, dimnames=list(1:3, paste0('V', 1:3))) write_fwf(X, 6) #> V1    V2    V3     #> A     D     G      #> B     E     H      #> C     F     I
